awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Collaborative Research: BigDataX: From theory to practice in Big Data computing at eXtreme scales
awd_abstract_narration:
This award extends the BigDataX program, a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at Illinois Institute of Technology (IIT) and the University of Chicago (UChicago). The BigDataX site focuses on undergraduate research in both the theory and practice of big data computing at extreme scales. BigDataX includes a diverse group of 10 undergraduate students, who will conduct research over a 10 week period, in the area of big data and how it will impact the design, analysis, and implementation of run-time systems and storage systems to support big data applications. This research will make extreme scale computing more tractable, touching every branch of computing in high-end computing and datacenters. These advancements will impact scientific discovery and economic development at the national level, and they will strengthen a wide range of research activities enabling efficient access, processing, storage, and sharing of valuable scientific data from many disciplines. The proposed work will place students in the middle of a technological revolution which will revolutionize the computing domain. 

The primary objective of this proposal is to promote a data-centric view of scientific and technical computing, at the intersection of distributed systems theory and practice. This proposal includes 6 mentors, with a variety of complementing expertise from theory to systems, distributed systems, storage management, and data science. The mentors have extensive experience in mentoring undergraduate students, collectively having worked with over one hundred students in research activities, publishing dozens peer-reviewed workshop/conference/journal papers at top venues together with undergraduate students. The students that will be part of the BigDataX program will be exposed to big data applications, large data sets, and various distributed systems such as the Mystic reconfigurable testbed at IIT, Chameleon cloud and Theta supercomputer at Argonne National Laboratory, the XSEDE national cyberinfrastructure, and the Amazon Web Services cloud.

por.por_cntn:
This project’s goals were to establish a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site named BigDataX (http://datasys.cs.iit.edu/grants/BigDataX/index.html), which focuses on undergraduate research in both theory and practice of big data computing at extreme scales. The primary objective of the site was to promote a data-centric view of scientific and technical computing, at the intersection of distributed systems in both theory and practice. The intellectual merit of the project was in the area of big data and addressed issues related to the design, analysis, and implementation of run-time systems and storage systems to support big data applications. The broader impact of this work has made extreme scale computing more tractable, touching many branches of computing in high-end computing, while placing undergraduate students in the middle of a technological revolution at the intersection of computer science, scientific computing, and big data. 

This project included 5 mentors with a variety of complementing expertise from theory to systems. This work included a comprehensive educational plan integrating 30 undergraduate students with senior PhD students with incremental manageable goals, aimed at allowing undergraduate students to achieve publishable results within the ten-week summer program. The students were immersed in a thriving research laboratory with many other high-school, undergraduate, masters, and PhD students participating in funded research work related to big data and distributed systems. Students were located in interdisciplinary laboratories at Illinois Institute of Technology and the University of Chicago. The PIs aimed to recruit most of the students from outside of the host institutions, focusing on recruiting students from institutions without research opportunities as well as women and minorities.

This REU program hosted 30 students from 2018–2021. Students produced 9 publications and gave at least two presentations each. In total, between 30% and 50% co-authored publications each year, and between 20% and 40% attended conferences each year. 

The program received 253 applications, of which 23% of the applicants were women, 21% were underrepresented minorities. 20% were 1stgeneration college students, and 43% were from primarily teaching only institutions. The program accepted 30 students (12% acceptance rate) including 11 women, 5 minorities, 9 first generation college students, and 6 students from primarily teaching only institutions. 

Some noteworthy research results can be highlighted by the awards received. In 2018, Luann Jung and Brendan Whitaker won the ACM Undergraduate Student Research Award at the IEEE/ACM SC18 conference for their paper titled “Measuring Swampiness: quantifying chaos in large heterogeneous data repositories.”  In 2019, Kathryn Leung and Meghan Kimball won 2nd place in the ACM Undergraduate Student Research Competition at IEEE/ACM SC19  conference for their paper titled “Walking the cost-accuracy tightrope: balancing trade-offs in data-intensive genomics.”  In 2021, Kevin Gao won 3rd place in the ACM Undergraduate Student Research Competition at IEEE/ACM SC21 for his paper titled “Regulating Traffic in a Crowded Cache: Overcoming the Container Explosion Problem."
